description.narrative: - Catalyzing the Country''s Renewable Energy Shift: Providing a sizable funding to renewable energy projects at the onset of the FIT introduction would expedite the country''s renewable energy shift. - Demonstration Effects: IFC''s support to the Project will demonstrate that these technologies - solar PV and biomass based on sugarcane trash - are replicable and can be scaled up. - Continuing Support to Sector Reform: IFC''s investment further endorses the country''s power sector reform, which is the most comprehensive in the region and among the key reasons for the country''s economic turn-around. - Energy Diversification and Security: The use of solar and biomass, both indigenous resources, will contribute to the country''s energy diversification and security.

The US$476.5 million proposed project will support the phased development and operation of a 155MW portfolio of co-located greenfield solar photovoltaic (PV) power plants with a total of 85MW and biomass power plants with a total of 70MW at three locations in Negros, Philippines (the Project). The Project would benefit from the co-location of intermittent and base-load power that would contribute to grid stabilization and achieve economy of scale derived from each co-located project using the same technology and engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) thus being replicable. The proposed investment includes the first utility-scale solar PV projects in the country and the first biomass project in the world utilizing sugar cane trash. These benefit from the Feed-in-Tariff (FIT) of PhP 9.68 (US$0.23) for solar and PhP 6.63 (US$0.16) for biomass. The first solar PV project was already commissioned in May 2014.

name.narrative: The Sponsors are developing the co-located solar PV and biomass projects at three locations in San Carlos City, La Carlota City, and Manapla City in Negros Island, Philippines. All these sites are in the heartlands of sugarcane farming, which are ideal for solar PV projects: the climatic conditions and terrain characteristics for sugarcane growing happen to be also suitable for solar PV - relatively high annual irradiance, flat terrains, and minimal shading obstructions.
